hotspots.label: Earthworm Body
hotspots.fact: Earthworms have long, tube-shaped bodies made up of ring-like segments called annuli. These segments help the worm stretch and compress as it moves through soil and tunnels underground.

hotspots.label: Worm Skin
hotspots.fact: Earthworm skin is moist and slimy, which helps them breathe! Unlike humans, earthworms don't have lungsâ€”they absorb oxygen directly through their skin, which is why they need to stay damp.

hotspots.label: Worm Movement
hotspots.fact: Earthworms move by contracting and relaxing their muscle segments in waves. This motion pushes them forward through soil, creating tunnels that help water and air reach plant roots.

hotspots.label: Grass Habitat
hotspots.fact: Earthworms live in soil under grass and plants. They are decomposers that break down dead leaves and organic matter, turning it into nutrient-rich soil that helps plants grow.
